title-group.article-title: Quantifying the Trajectory of Percutaneous Endoscopic Lumbar Discectomy in 3D Lumbar Models Based on Automated MR Image Segmentation—A Cross‐Sectional Study

sec.title: Objective
sec.p: Creating a 3D lumbar model and planning a personalized puncture trajectory has an advantage in establishing the working channel for percutaneous endoscopic lumbar discectomy (PELD). However, existing 3D lumbar models, which seldom include lumbar nerves and dural sac reconstructions, primarily depend on CT images for preoperative trajectory planning. Therefore, our study aims to further investigate the relationship between different virtual working channels and the 3D lumbar model, which includes automated MR image segmentation of lumbar bone, nerves, and dural sac at the L4/L5 level.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: Preoperative lumbar MR images of 50 patients with L4/L5 lumbar disc herniation were collected from a teaching hospital between March 2020 and July 2020. Automated MR image segmentation was initially used to create a 3D model of the lumbar spine, including the L4 vertebrae, L5 vertebrae, intervertebral disc, L4 nerves, dural sac, and skin. Thirty were then randomly chosen from the segmentation results to clarify the relationship between various virtual working channels and the lumbar 3D model. A bivariate Spearman's rank correlation analysis was used in this study.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Preoperative MR images of 50 patients (34 males, mean age 45.6 ± 6 years) were used to train and validate the automated segmentation model, which had mean Dice scores of 0.906, 0.891, 0.896, 0.695, 0.892, and 0.892 for the L4 vertebrae, L5 vertebrae, intervertebral disc, L4 nerves, dural sac, and skin, respectively. With an increase in the coronal plane angle (CPA), there was a reduction in the intersection volume involving the L4 nerves and atypical structures. Conversely, the intersection volume encompassing the dural sac, L4 inferior articular process, and L5 superior articular process increased; the total intersection volume showed a fluctuating pattern: it initially decreased, followed by an increase, and then decreased once more. As the cross‐section angle (CSA) increased, there was a rise in the intersection volume of both the L4 nerves and the dural sac; the intersection volume involving the L4 inferior articular process grew while that of the L5 superior articular process diminished; the overall intersection volume and the intersection volume of atypical structures initially decreased, followed by an increase.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In terms of regularity, the optimal angles for L4/L5 PELD are a CSA of 15° and a CPA of 15°–20°, minimizing harm to the vertebral bones, facet joint, spinal nerves, and dural sac. Additionally, our 3D preoperative planning method could enhance puncture trajectories for individual patients, potentially advancing surgical navigation, robots, and artificial intelligence in PELD procedures.

abstract.p: Constructing a network for automatic lumbar MR image segmentation. Evaluated the effects of different puncture angles of the PELD procedure on the lumbar vertebral bone structure, nerve, and dural sac.

institution-wrap.institution: National Natural Sciences Foundation of China

p.mixed-citation: Z.Su, Y.Wang, C.Huang, et al., “Quantifying the Trajectory of Percutaneous Endoscopic Lumbar Discectomy in 3D Lumbar Models Based on Automated MR Image Segmentation—A Cross‐Sectional Study,” Orthopaedic Surgery17, no. 9 (2025): 2689–2698, 10.1111/os.70112.PMC1240487440745956

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Lumbar disc herniation (LDH) is the most common cause of low back pain (LBP) and sciatica [1, 2], with the majority of lumbar disc herniations occurring at the L4/L5 level [3]. Percutaneous endoscopic lumbar discectomy (PELD) is a reliable treatment method [4]. However, establishing the working channel of PELD may be impeded by the bony structures of the spine. An improperly aligned working channel can compromise the stability of the spine by excessive bone removal, which might even result in surgical failure. Additionally, the repeated reorientation of the channel not only extends the duration of the procedure and elevates the cumulative radiation dose to which both the patient and the surgeon are exposed, but also heightens the risk of nerve and dural sac injury, potentially resulting in postoperative dysesthesia [5, 6, 7]. Therefore, the key to successful PELD surgery is the ability to select an appropriate puncture trajectory in establishing the working channel.

Reconstructing a three‐dimensional (3D) lumbar model for a patient and subsequently planning an individualized puncture trajectory offers the advantage of improving the efficiency of establishing the working channel in PELD [8, 9, 10]. Huang et al. [8] present a method to evaluate the relationship between 3D lumbar vertebrae anatomy and the working channel in PELD, without addressing the trajectory's effect on the lumbar nerves and dural sac during path planning. Exploring the relationship between the 3D lumbar nerves, dural sac, and working channel in path planning is crucial, but accurately and swiftly reconstructing the 3D lumbar nerves and dural sac poses several challenges. Automated MR image segmentation, as one of artificial intelligence, has the potential to segment anatomical tissues on medical images accurately and quickly [11, 12]. Several researchers have endeavored to utilize artificial intelligence for the 3D reconstruction of lumbar vertebrae bone, nerves, and dural sac to create a 3D lumbar model [12, 13]. However, the application of this 3D lumbar model based on automated MR image segmentation for path planning in PELD remains limited.

Therefore, building on the previous studies, our study aims to further investigate the relationship between different virtual working channels and the 3D lumbar model, which includes automated MR image segmentation of lumbar bone, nerves, and dural sac. Our main purposes of this study can be summarized as follows:
Automated MR image segmentation was initially used to create a 3D model of the lumbar spine, including the L4 vertebral bone structure, L5 vertebral bone structure, intervertebral discs, L4 nerve, dura, and skin.
Following the reconstruction of the 3D lumbar models, the virtual working channel was strategically positioned within the intervertebral foramen to obtain the intersection volume between different virtual working channels and the 3D lumbar model.
Calculating the intersection volume between different virtual working channels and the 3D lumbar model was used to clarify the regularity between the puncture trajectory and the L4/L5 lumbar spine, thereby aiding in selecting an appropriate puncture trajectory in establishing the working channel for PELD.

sec.title: Ethnic and Registration
sec.p: This study was approved by the Ethics Committee of an anonymous hospital. Signed informed consents were obtained from all patients prior to the commencement of the study (No. 2020 K05‐1). The study was undertaken according to the Guideline: Strengthening the reporting of cohort studies in surgery (STROCSS 2021) [14] and in accordance with the latest version of the Declaration of Helsinki.

sec.title: Patient Characteristics
sec.p: This study included 50 patients treated for lumbar disc herniation at our hospital from March 2020 to July 2020. Inclusion criteria were as follows: (1) L4/L5 lumbar disc herniation; (2) no contraindications to magnetic resonance examination; (3) patient age ≥ 18 years. Exclusion criteria included the following: (1) previous history of spinal surgery; (2) spinal deformity, including congenital deformity, scoliosis or kyphosis, lumbar spondylolisthesis; (3) vertebral infection, including lumbar tuberculosis or intervertebral space infection; (4) patients with lumbar vertebral fracture, or with spinal tumor; (5) serious artifacts on MR images. The final study group comprised 28 male and 22 female participants, aged between 22 and 82 years. The mean age was 45.6 years, and the mean body mass index was 22.9 kg/m2. Three dimensional T2‐weighted sampling perfection with application‐optimized contrast with various flip‐angle evolutions (3D T2W‐SPACE) sequences [15] scans were performed for all participants at the L4/L5 level using a 3T MR unit (Magnetom Verio; Siemens, Erlangen, Germany). All MR scans were saved in DICOM format.

sec.title: Establishing the Automatic MR Image Segmentation Model
sec.p: The dataset consists of 50 MR volumes at the L4/L5 level collected from our hospital. Manual segmentation and labeling of vertebrae bone (L4 and L5 vertebrae bone), disc, dural sac, L4 nerves, and skin by three experts were conducted in Mimics 19.0 (Materialize, Leuven, Belgium) and then used as the ground truth for training of deep learning algorithms. First, the lumbar structures were meticulously outlined by one expert and followed by an independent review of two experienced experts. Finally, each expert voted on the areas that were disagreed upon. All of the MR volumes were preprocessed via resampling, cropping, and padding operation before training. Our group developed an automatic lumbar spine structure segmentation model using a 3D U‐shaped architecture network (3D‐UNet) [12]. This model outputs seven channels, including the background, L4 vertebral bone, intervertebral disc, L5 vertebral bone, L4 nerves, dural sac, and skin (Figure 1A–C). We trained and validated the model using lumbar MRI data from 50 participants. The model automatically segmented the anatomical structures of the lumbar spine to generate 3D masks, and the 3D anatomical structures were then reconstructed using Mimics 19.0. Thirty 3D lumbar models were randomly selected to evaluate the intersection volume between various virtual working channels and the three‐dimensional lumbar spine anatomy.

caption.p: Constructing a network for automatic lumbar MR image segmentation. (A) Manual segmentation of lumbar MR in multiple views. (B) 3D U‐net network diagram of the automatic lumbar MR image segmentation network. (C) 3D reconstruction model after automatic image segmentation.

sec.title: Reconstructing 3D Anatomical Structures and Assessment
sec.p: The automatic segmentation model segmented the MR images to generate 3D masks of each structure, which were imported and reconstructed in Mimics 19.0 (Materialize, Leuven, Belgium) to generate a 3D anatomical model of the L4/L5 level. The puncture target point of PELD was defined as the projection point of the medial border of the bilateral facet joints on the midline of the intervertebral space in the coronal position of the lumbar spine. Using the puncture target point as the origin, we created a cylinder in Mimics (8 mm in diameter and 150 mm long to simulate the outer diameter of PELD's working channel) as the virtual working channel and converted it into the Standard Template Library (STL) data format. This cylinder, along with the puncture target point (situated at the center of the ventral end of the cylinder) and the 3D lumbar model, were imported into the 3‐Matic software. We then established and displayed the world coordinate system (Figure 2A), setting the puncture target point as the center. The angle of the cylinder's movement along the Z‐axis of this system was defined as the coronal plane angle (CPA), and its angle along the Y‐axis was the cross section angle (CSA) (Figure 2B). We initially set the virtual working channel trajectory at CPA 0° and CSA 0°, then rotated the channel on the 3D model at specific angles (CPA 0°, 5°, 10°, 15°, 20°, 25°, and 30°; CSA 0°, 5°, 10°, 15°, 20°, 25°, and 30°), keeping the puncture target as the pivot. Since the virtual working channel is a solid cylinder, the sum of the volumes it intersects with each structure is the total intersection volume (Figure 2C). The overlapping region between the working channel and the L4 nerve was defined as the intersection volume of the L4 nerve; the overlapping region between the working channel and the L5 superior articular process was defined as the intersection volume of the L5 superior articular process; the overlapping region between the working channel and atypical anatomical structures (such as vertebral bodies, pedicles, and transverse processes of L4 and L5) were defined as the intersection volume of atypical structures. The volume of intersecting each lumbar structure and the virtual working channel is automatically obtained by the Mimics software (Figure 2D).

caption.p: Angular variation of the virtual working channel and quantification of the overlapping portion between the channel and the lumbar structures. (A) Angle variation of the virtual working channel in the Y‐axis (cross‐section angulation, CSA) and Z‐axis (coronal plane angulation, CPA) of the world coordinate system. (B) The virtual working channels move along the Y‐axis and Z‐axis, respectively, as illustrated (the yellow cylinder represents the virtual workin channel state at CPA 0° and CSA 5°, while the blue cylinder indicates the virtual working channel state at CPA 0° and CSA 5°). (C) The cylinder indicates the virtual working channel state at CPA 15° and CSA 30°. (D) The Mimics software automatically calculates the intersection volume between the working channel and the lumbar structures (the blue portion indicated by the black arrow represents the intersection volume of atypical structures).

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: All analyzed data were processed using SPSS 26.0 software for statistical analysis (IBM Corporation, Armonk, NY). Experimental measurements were expressed as mean ± standard deviation. The potential correlation between the virtual working channel and the overlapping volume of lumbar spine structures was assessed using a bivariate Spearman's rank correlation analysis, with a statistically significant difference of p < 0.05.

sec.title: The Performance of the Automatic Segmentation Model
sec.p: The performance of the automatic segmentation model for segmenting lumbar spine MR images of 50 patients is presented in Table 1. The model segmented the L4 vertebral bone structure, L5 vertebral bone structure, intervertebral disc, L4 nerves, dural sac, and skin, obtaining high average Dice scores of 0.906, 0.891, 0.896, 0.695, 0892, and 0.892, respectively (Figure 3A). The average segmentation precision of the segmentation model for the L4 vertebral bone structure, L5 vertebral bone structure, intervertebral disc, L4 nerves, dural sac, and skin was 0.903, 0.919, 0.895, 0.743, 0.889, and 0.884, respectively (Figure 3B). The average recalls of the segmentation model for the L4 vertebral bone structure, L5 vertebral bone structure, intervertebral disc, L4 nerves, dural sac, and skin were 0.914, 0.873, 0.902, 0.669, 0.899, and 0.905 (Figure 3C), respectively.

caption.p: Results of automated MR image segmentation performances at the L4/L5 level.

fn.p: Note: Data are means of fivefold cross‐validation scores. L4 = 4th lumbar vertebra bone, L5 = 5th lumbar vertebra bone.

caption.p: Evaluation metrics for automatic segmentation of lumbar spine MR images by artificial intelligence. (A) dice score, (B) precision, and (C) recall. The segmented structures include L4 vertebral bone, intervertebral disc, L5 vertebral bone, L4 nerve, dura, and skin.

sec.title: Total Intersection Volume
sec.p: The trend of the total intersection volume between the virtual working channel and the lumbar spine structures at different angles is displayed in Figure 4A. With the CSA held constant (0°–20°), the total intersection volume exhibited a pattern of initially decreasing and then increasing as the CPA increased. In the CSA 25° and 30° groups, the total intersection volume showed a trend of increasing and then decreasing with the increasing value of CPA (r = 0.111, p < 0.001). When CPA was a constant (0°–30°), the total intersection volume showed a trend of decreasing and then increasing with an increasing value of CSA (r = 0.071, p < 0.001). The total intersection volumes between the virtual working channel and the lumbar spine structures from different angles are presented in Table 2.

caption.p: The bar graph of the intersection volume. CSA, cross section angulation; CPA, coronal plane angulation. (A) A bar graph of the total intersection volume, CPA: r = 0.111, p < 0.001; CSA: r = 0.071, p < 0.001. (B) A bar graph of the intersection volume of L4 inferior articular process, CPA: r = 0.176, p < 0.001; CSA: r = 0.094, p < 0.001. (C) A bar graph of the intersection volume of L5 superior articular process, CPA: r = 0.510, p < 0.001; CSA: r = −0.186, p < 0.001. (D) A bar graph of the intersection volume of atypical structures, CPA: r = −0.100, p < 0.001; CSA: r = 0.504, p < 0.001.
Results of the intersection volumes between the virtual working channel and the L5 superior articular process, L4 nerve and all lumbar structures from different angles.

fn.p: Note: Data are means of intersection volume.
Abbreviations: CPA, coronal plane angle; CSA, cross section angle; SAP, superior articular process.

sec.title: Intersection Volume of L4 Inferior Articular Process and L5 Superior Articular Process
sec.p: The trends of the intersection volumes of the L4 inferior articular process and the L5 superior articular process with the virtual working channel are demonstrated in Figure 4B,C. When the CSA was constant (0°–30°), the volume of the L4 inferior articular and L5 superior articular processes increased with the concomitant increase of the CPA (r = 0.176, p < 0.001; r = 0.510, p < 0.001), while the intersection volume of the L4 inferior articular process when the CPA was constant (0°–30°), the volume of the L4 inferior articular process increased with the increase in CSA (r = 0.094, p < 0.001). However, the intersection volume of the L5 superior articular process decreased with increasing CSA (r = −0.186, p < 0.001). The intersection volumes between the virtual working channel and the L5 superior articular process from different angles are presented in Table 2.

sec.title: Intersection Volume of Atypical Structures
sec.p: As shown in Figure 4D, when the CSA was constant (0°–15°), the intersection volume gradually decreased as the CPA increased. As the CPA rose, the volume in the CSA 20° group displayed a trend of decreasing, then increasing, and subsequently decreasing again. In contrast, the CSA 25° and 30° groups exhibited a pattern of first increasing and then decreasing (r = −0.100, p < 0.001). When the CPA was constant (0°–15°, 30°), the intersection volume showed a tendency to decrease, followed by an increase with the concomitant increase of the CSA. The volume gradually increased with the rise of the CSA in the CPA 20° and 25° groups (r = 0.504, p < 0.001).

sec.title: Intersection Volume of the L4 Nerve and Dural Sac
sec.p: The trend of the intersection volume between the virtual working channel and the L4 nerve at different angles is illustrated in Figure 5A. In each CSA group (0°–30°), the intersection volume of L4 nerve decreased with the increase of CPA (r = −0.562, p < 0.001). In the CPA 0° groups, the intersection volume of L4 nerves showed a tendency to increase and then decrease with the increase of CSA. However, when the CPA was a fixed constant (5°–30°), the intersection volume of L4 nerves gradually increased with the increase of CSA (r = 0.130, p < 0.001). The intersection volumes between the virtual working channel and the L4 nerve from different angles are presented in Table 2. The trend of the intersection volume about the virtual working channel and the dural sac at different angles is presented in Figure 5B. When the CSA was a constant (0°–30°), the intersection volume of the dural sac tended to increase with the increase of the CPA (r = 0.247, p < 0.001). When the CPA was kept constant (0°–30°), the intersection volume of the dural sac increased with increasing CSA (r = 0.112, p < 0.001).

caption.p: The bar graph of the intersection volume. CSA, cross section angulation; CPA, coronal plane angulation. (A) A bar graph of the intersection volume of L4 nerve, CPA: r = −0.562, p < 0.001; CSA: r = 0.130, p < 0.001. (B) A bar graph of the intersection volume of dural sac, CPA: r = 0.247, p < 0.001; CSA: r = 0.112, p < 0.00.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The key findings of this study show that the ideal angulation for L4/L5 PELD is a CSA of 15° and a CPA of 15°–20°, resulting in minimal damage to the bony structure, facet joint, spinal nerves, and dural sac. Our 3D preoperative planning method shows promise in optimizing puncture trajectories for individual patients in PELD procedures.

sec.title: The Effect of Improperly Oriented Punctures
sec.p: Improperly oriented punctures in the PELD working channels can result in unsuccessful surgery and a range of postoperative complications [5]. A suitable puncture trajectory should not only aim to minimize damage to bone structures, but more crucially, avoid harming spinal nerves and dura to prevent complications like pain, postoperative dysesthesia, and dural tears [7]. Previous studies have shown the clinical feasibility of using 3D models for simulating surgical trajectories [9, 10]. However, improvements can still be made regarding the types of images used, the comprehensive representation of the anatomical model, and the timeliness of these simulations. In our study, the automatic segmentation model underwent training and testing with lumbar MR data, completing the segmentation process within seconds and achieving high dice scores. We then performed a quantitative assessment of the relationships between different virtual working channels and 3D lumbar spinal structures, such as lumbar vertebrae bone, spinal nerves, and dural sac. This was accomplished by reconstructing a 3D lumbar model using a randomly selected subset of the segmentation results and positioning virtual channels at various angles in the coronal plane and cross‐section.

sec.title: 3D Lumbar Models Generated From Medical Images Using Automatic Segmentation
sec.p: The image data used in this study was MR sequence 3D T2W‐SPACE (3D isotropic T2‐weighted TSE sampling refinement using different flip angle evolution to optimize contrast). This MR sequence has the advantages of high‐resolution multiplanar reconstructed images and thin‐layer scanning [15, 16]. Differing from the traditional reliance on CT images to construct 3D models, which come with disadvantages like high radiation exposure and poor soft tissue contrast, the MR sequence used in this study is more effective in visualizing soft tissues like spinal nerves and dural sac [17, 18]. Consequently, the 3D lumbar models generated from thin‐layer MR images have a higher degree of integrity. Unlike previous studies on 3D lumbar spine models that focused primarily on segmenting vertebral bones and intervertebral discs [8, 19, 20], this study is capable of effectively simultaneously segmenting not only those structures but also soft tissues, such as spinal nerves and dural sac. The automated segmentation method used in this study accurately reflects the distribution of the nerves, outperforms previous manual segmentation studies in terms of segmentation accuracy and segmentation time, and can provide detailed 3D anatomical structures for preoperative surgery evaluation and path planning.

The working channel of PELD is not only obstructed by bony structures such as facet joints, but may also damage the exiting nerve roots and dural sac. This would lead to complications such as postoperative sensory deficits and cerebrospinal fluid leakage [5]. Previous research aimed at minimizing spinal nerve injury measured the proximity of the nerve roots to surrounding structures and the height of the intervertebral foramen using two‐dimensional MR imaging [21, 22]. However, planning a suitable puncture trajectory with 2D images is difficult because they do not directly show the 3D relationship between the working channel and adjacent tissue structures. Chen et al. [20] constructed the 3D preoperative planning software (TE‐Guider) for PELD based on CT images, obtaining the ideal path by the method of specifying the position of the herniated fragments, restricting the puncture angles on the view of the lateral, dorsal, and axial, and collision detection. Huang et al. [8] reconstructed the preoperative CT images and then adjusted the angle of the virtual trajectory to summarize the most optimal puncture angle of the surgical working channel. Nevertheless, these studies did not accomplish the reconstruction of soft tissues, including spinal nerves and dural sac. Instead, they focused on preventing injury to the exiting nerve roots by examining the relative positional relationship between the intervertebral foramen and the facet joints [8, 10, 20].

sec.title: Puncture Angulation of PELD
sec.p: By precisely segmenting various anatomical structures of the lumbar spine, including the L4 nerves and dural sac, using the automatic segmentation model, we deduced the patterns between PELD surgical trajectories and lumbar spine structures at varying angles. This was based on data from 30 patients, encompassing a total of 60 foramina. This analysis offers spine surgeons a range of preferable puncture angles for L4/L5 surgical trajectories, thereby assisting them in rapidly establishing a safe and appropriate working channel. The findings of this study indicate that the least damage to the lumbar anatomical structures from the working channel occurred at a CSA of 15° and a CPA of 15°–20°. Maintaining a lower CSA while moderately increasing the CPA can lessen the intersection volume between the working channel and the nerve; lower CSA and CPA values also help in reducing the risk of dural sac injury. However, the angles resulting in minimal total damage identified in this study do not align with those reported in previous research. Huang et al. [8] concluded that the ideal angulation for L4/L5 PELD is CPA 5°–10° and CSA 5°–10°, which can lead to a relatively low level of total damage to the bony structure. We suspect this inconsistency arises from the different methods used to determine the puncture target point in previous studies compared to ours. Typically, previous research defined the target point as the midpoint of the posterior margins of the L4 and L5 vertebral bodies in the transverse and sagittal planes. In contrast, our approach involved using the projection point of the medial border of the bilateral facet joints on the midline of the intervertebral space in the lumbar spine's coronal position. This choice was based on the observation that herniated disc was often located on the posterior lateral aspect of the vertebral body [23]. Herniations below the intervertebral foramen tend to produce more pronounced symptoms and are frequently targeted by clinicians during puncture.

Moreover, minimizing total damage is not the sole criterion for an ideal trajectory. Postoperative pain and motor weakness, often resulting from spinal nerve injury due to instrument irritation or mishandling, are more common and can significantly impact a patient's recovery and postoperative quality of life [5, 7, 8]. Therefore, moderate damage to bony structures is considered more acceptable compared to damage to spinal nerves. Our study indicates that the intersection volume between the L4 nerves and the working channel positively correlates with the CSA angle and negatively with the CPA angle. This aligns with findings from previous studies, like Choi et al. [24], who showed that the distance between the nerve roots and the facet at the lower disc level is crucial for spinal nerve root injury (14). Huang et al. [8], although not directly reconstructing the spinal nerve roots in 3D, confirmed that with a higher CSA value, an increased CPA value led to a greater proportion of the intersection volume between the working channel and the facet joint, reducing the overlap with the exiting nerve roots. Unlike these studies [8, 10], our research included 3D reconstruction of the exiting nerve roots, allowing us to directly assess the intersection volume between the working channel and the nerves. This study not only corroborates the findings of Huang et al. [8] but also uncovers a new insight: the overlap between the L4 nerve and the working channel is minimized when the working channel has a low CSA and a high CPA (for instance, CSA at 0° and CPA at 30°, results in an intersection volume of L4 nerve lower than 20 mm3). These findings emphasize that increasing the CPA and decreasing the CSA of the working channel during surgery, which involves positioning it as close as possible to the facet joints, can significantly reduce the risk of nerve injury from the working channel.

sec.title: Strengths and Limitations
sec.p: In this study, the relationship between different virtual working channels and 3D lumbar spinal structures has been summarized across multiple patients, aiding in selecting an appropriate puncture trajectory for working channel establishment. For an individual patient, the 3D preoperative planning approach described in our research has demonstrated advantages in planning puncture trajectories. The initial findings discussed in this study could aid in the future advancement and application of surgical navigation systems, surgical robots, and artificial intelligence technologies within the realm of PELD procedures.

This study also has some limitations. First, it does not include vascular segmentation, and damage to blood vessels by the working channel could lead to postoperative hematoma, a concern we aim to address in future research. Second, the evaluation was confined to the intersection volume between the working channel and the L4/L5 lumbar spine anatomical structure. Third, our assessment of the relationship between various virtual working channels and the L4/L5 lumbar spine was based on preoperative MR data from 30 patients with lumbar disc herniation. Since the MR images were derived from patients with this condition, there is an inherent bias, making the results less representative of the general population. Additional data and clinical trials may be necessary to validate our findings. Lastly, this study utilized preoperative MR data to analyze the relationship between various virtual working channels and the 3D lumbar model. It is important to note that the morphology of different spinal structures may change during the intraoperative phase. Multi‐modality image registration is possible for solving this problem [25], and we further intend to implement automatic registration between preoperative images (spine MR or CT) and intraoperative images to address the challenges posed by anatomical morphology changes.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This study evaluated the intersection volume of the PELD working channel with L4/L5 lumbar spine structures at various angles to determine a trajectory that minimizes anatomical damage. The ideal angulation for L4/L5 PELD is a CSA of 15° and a CPA of 15°–20°, resulting in minimal damage to the bony structure, facet joint, spinal nerves, and dural sac. Moreover, our 3D preoperative planning method shows promise in optimizing puncture trajectories for individual patients, potentially advancing surgical navigation, surgical robots, and artificial intelligence technologies in PELD procedures.
